pr_title: Fix return type of array subscript

timeline.author: findepi

timeline.bodyText: we prefer comments on line before
timeline.author: findepi

timeline.bodyText: was lack of this cast exploitable with any test today?
timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: After the change I made to ArraySubscriptOperator, I am not aware of any functions that would require this cast, but I wouldn't be surprised if some existed.
replies.author: jirassimok

timeline.bodyText: Why equals? Would "object.class.isAssignableFrom returntype && returntype != sqlReturnType.getJavaType()" be better?
timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: This check and cast isn't in the PR any more, but yes, that probably would have been better.
replies.author: jirassimok

timeline.bodyText:
squash! Fix array subscripting for SQL types represented as Objects

remove squash from the message
timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: I'm going to squash it in the future.
replies.author: jirassimok

timeline.bodyText:
Typically this comment would go before this line (standalone).
But I think it's fine to go without a comment at all here
timeline.author: findepi

timeline.bodyText: This got reverted. Was that an abandoned attempt approach?
timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: Yes; see my initial PR comment.
replies.author: jirassimok

timeline.author: findepi

replies.bodyText: I've removed that check and expanded the test slightly.
replies.author: jirassimok

timeline.author: findepi

timeline.bodyText:
The check was previously reversed, so what is actually satisfied is equality.
And indeed, the stack representation is not polymorphic today, so equality can be demanded.
timeline.author: findepi
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -2025,11 +2025,13 @@ private static void verifyMethodHandleSignature(BoundSignature boundSignature, F
         Type returnType = boundSignature.getReturnType();
         switch (convention.getReturnConvention()) {
             case FAIL_ON_NULL:
-                verifyFunctionSignature(methodType.returnType().isAssignableFrom(returnType.getJavaType()),
+                verifyFunctionSignature(
+                        returnType.getJavaType().isAssignableFrom(methodType.returnType()),

replies.bodyText:
That's a good point.
But given how many tests fail with this change, it doesn't seem like equality is the right solution, so I'm going to take it out of the PR.
replies.author: jirassimok

timeline.bodyText:
a Block is a special case.
it works today, dunno why
assertFunction("CAST((ARRAY[ARRAY['xxx']])[1] AS json)", JSON, "[\"xxx\"]"); // block

but still worth having a test
note: cast here is to JSON, because of #6347
this anomaly in test cases leads to a question whether assertSubscriptCast is worth having separate or inline back. I'd inline.
timeline.author: findepi
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -749,6 +750,23 @@ public void testSubscript()
         assertDecimalFunction("ARRAY [2.22222222222222222, 2.3][1]", decimal("2.22222222222222222"));
     }
 
+    @Test
+    public void testSubscriptReturnType()
+    {
+        // Test return type of array subscript by passing it to another operation
+        // One test for each specialization of the operator
+        assertSubscriptCast("true", "true"); // boolean
+        assertSubscriptCast("1234", "1234"); // long
+        assertSubscriptCast("1.23", "1.23"); // double
+        assertSubscriptCast("IPADDRESS '127.0.0.1'", "127.0.0.1"); // slice
+        assertSubscriptCast("TIMESTAMP '1970-01-01 00:00:00.000000001'", "1970-01-01 00:00:00.000000001"); // object (LongTimestamp)

replies.bodyText: Or instead, I could use JSON for all of them. 👀
replies.author: jirassimok

timeline.bodyText: select CAST((ARRAY [TIMESTAMP '1970-01-01 00:00:00.000000001'])[1] AS VARCHAR); does not fail even without your fixes.
timeline.author: losipiuk
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -749,6 +750,23 @@ public void testSubscript()
         assertDecimalFunction("ARRAY [2.22222222222222222, 2.3][1]", decimal("2.22222222222222222"));
     }
 
+    @Test
+    public void testSubscriptReturnType()
+    {
+        // Test return type of array subscript by passing it to another operation
+        // One test for each specialization of the operator
+        assertSubscriptCast("true", "true"); // boolean
+        assertSubscriptCast("1234", "1234"); // long
+        assertSubscriptCast("1.23", "1.23"); // double
+        assertSubscriptCast("IPADDRESS '127.0.0.1'", "127.0.0.1"); // slice
+        assertSubscriptCast("TIMESTAMP '1970-01-01 00:00:00.000000001'", "1970-01-01 00:00:00.000000001"); // object (LongTimestamp)

replies.bodyText:
assertFunction executes the expression five different ways. At least one of them involves manually compiling the expression, which makes the bug occur.
It fails at FunctionAssertions line 502. But to get there, the query had to already succeed as-is on line 493.
replies.author: jirassimok

replies.bodyText:
@losipiuk this query doesn't fail, as the subscript (and everything else) is taken care of by the expression interpreter, during optimization, doesn't reach compiled code at all
the TestArrayOperators exercises both optimized and non-optimized expressions.
replies.author: findepi

timeline.bodyText:
I was planning to add suggestion to add extra casting in the generated code, as I was expecting array subscript is not only affected function.
For example I expected MapSubscriptOperator to have same issue. But for some reason I do not reproduce the problem with
CREATE TABLE test (col MAP(VARCHAR,TIMESTAMP(7)));

interesting.
timeline.author: losipiuk

replies.bodyText:
I had the cast you suggested until I realized that MapSubscriptOperator doesn't have the bug. Then I copied the current solution from that class.
Another option I considered early on was to perform this same MethodType conversion in generateFullInvocation. I did it wrong at first, and now I think it's not quite as clean a solution. Yes, it would prevent this exact error in the future, but it seems like a better idea to trust each SQL function to correctly set its return type. (I've pushed this change as 0e34890.)
Maybe this should be in a doc comment on SqlScalarFunction.specialize.
replies.author: jirassimok

replies.bodyText: Should we maybe that method handle return type match the type in FunctionRegistry.specializeScalarFunction?
replies.author: losipiuk

replies.bodyText: That sounds reasonable to me. Let's consider this as a follow up maybe?
replies.author: findepi

timeline.message:
Fix array subscripting for SQL types represented as Objects

When subscripting arrays containing SQL types represented as Java
Objects (as opposed to long-, double-, or Slice-based types), the
type returned was previously Object.

This caused compiler failures when attempting to perform any operation
after subscripting (i.e. `fn(arr[1])`), because of the mismatch
between the actual type (Object) and type expected by the following
operation (e.g. LongTimestamp).

Fix array subscripting for SQL types represented as Objects

When subscripting arrays containing SQL types represented as Java
Objects (as opposed to long-, double-, or Slice-based types), the
type returned was previously Object.

This caused compiler failures when attempting to perform any operation
after subscripting (i.e. `fn(arr[1])`), because of the mismatch
between the actual type (Object) and type expected by the following
operation (e.g. LongTimestamp).
